an4.164:4.1: “Mendicants, there are four ways of practice.
an4.164:4.3: Impatient practice, patient practice, taming practice, and calming practice.
an4.164:4.5: It’s when someone abuses, annoys, or argues with you, and you abuse, annoy, or argue right back at them.
an4.164:4.6: This is called the impatient practice.
an4.164:5.2: It’s when someone abuses, annoys, or argues with you, and you don’t abuse, annoy, or argue back at them.
an4.164:5.3: This is called the patient practice.
an4.164:6.2: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
an4.164:6.3: If the faculty of sight was left unrestrained, bad unwholesome qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint,
an4.164:6.6: Hearing a sound with the ears … Smelling an odor with the nose … Tasting a flavor with the tongue … Feeling a touch with the body … Knowing a phenomena with the mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
an4.164:6.7: If the faculty of mind was left unrestrained, bad unwholesome qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint,
an4.164:6.10: This is called the taming practice.
an4.164:7.2: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t tolerate a sensual thought that’s arisen, but gives it up, gets rid of it, calms it, eliminates it, and exterminates it.
an4.164:7.3: They don’t tolerate a malicious thought … They don’t tolerate a harmful thought … They don’t tolerate any bad, unwholesome qualities that have arisen, but give them up, get rid of them, calm them, eliminate them, and exterminate them.
an4.164:7.4: This is called the calming practice.
an4.164:7.5: These are the four ways of practice.”
